awd_titl_txt: RAPID: STEM faculty support to address impacts from COVID-19 on Tribal Colleges and Universities Program institutions
awd_abstract_narration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the STEM curricular offerings at these institutions expands the opportunities of their students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be culturally significant, and encourages a community and generational appreciation for science and mathematics education. The sustainability of STEM instructional capacity gains is significantly enhanced by retaining the talent of credentialed STEM faculty. This project aligns directly with that goal.

The COVID-19 pandemic caused major disruptions to institutions of higher education. For tribal colleges and universities, whose core operating funds are directly aligned with student enrollment, drops in enrollment equate to loss of funding. To mitigate against detrimental pandemic-related effects on STEM instructional capacity, this award will support the salary and professional development of one full-time STEM faculty member at Salish Kootenai College. This TCUP STEM Faculty award is intended to help maintain Salish Kootenai College’s STEM program as the college recovers from the deleterious impact of the pandemic.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes from this grant were to stablize the faculty arrangements at Salish Kootenai College (SKC) after the COVID 19 pandemic. This grant enzbled the Life Sciences Department to teach, develop curriculum, recruit and retain Native American students who otherwise would not have succeeded in continuing their education after th interuption of the pandemic. The faculty member supported was able to increase the institutional capacity through increasing the student count in STEM and add to the current curriculum experiential learning experiences for the students in order to retain, recruit and enhance undergraduate education at SKC. 

The specific courses impacted by this award were the Cellular and Molecular Biology courses for year two Life Sciences students, Biology of Living Systems for first year students of several STEM programs at SKC (including LIfe Sciences), and bioinformatics course development for year two and year three students. 

Institutional numbers indicate there is an increase in Life Sciences numbers from post COVID to the fall enrollment for 2024. This increase is nearly a 50% increase in enrollment from a low of 8 in post COVID to 15 for the fall of 2024. Additionally, as SKC is on a quarter system, courses will not start until the second week of September, which allows for the possibility that more students will enroll by that start date. 

The courses delivered by the faculty member in this award had a direct impact on this increase by which students in the first and second year of General Sciences have completed their Associates degrees and decided to continue into a Bachelor's of Life Sciences program. The faculty member has worked hard to connect with students, to engage them in coursework, and to increase the laboratory exposure through the courses to increase student interest thus leading to our increased enrollment numbers. 

Therefore, the outcomes by this award were: (1) the ability for the Life Sciences Department at SKC to continue to offer a science courses in the molecular and biological sciences (2) add to course materials the laboratory experiences (3) recruit and retain stduents in STEM at SKC. 


Last Modified: 07/30/2024
Modified by: Christina L Rush
